Introduction
Individuals admitted to the acute hospital setting who present with mental health
problems will often require additional specialist input, care and support from multi agency services.
The legal framework which managers, doctors, nurses, social workers and the

Police must follow is set out within the Mental Health Act 1983,amended 2007 (“the MHA”). The MHA sets out the statutory framework for the compulsory detention of people in hospital for assessment or treatment of their mental disorder. It also contains the provisions which must be complied with for compulsory treatment of that mental disorder. The provisions for compulsory detention and treatment only apply to treatment for the person's mental disorder or the physical consequences of that mental disorder, e.g. anorexia nervosa. In addition to this, implementation of the MHA is carried out through the MHA – the revised Code of Practice (2015) which gives guidance on how the MHA should be applied in order to provide safe, effective care and treatment in a timely manner and also protects the patient's rights and autonomy. Although the Code of Practice is not a part of the Act, practitioners have to have good reason for departing from it.
The Trust aims to take all reasonable steps to ensure the safety and
independence of all its patients, and respects the rights of patients to make their own decisions about their care.
The Trust also has an obligation under the Health and Safety at Work Act 1974 to
ensure their employees and anyone else who could be affected by their work (such as visitors and other members of the public), are kept safe from harm and that their health is not affected.
Health and Safety at Work etc. Act 1974 (legislation.gov.uk)
Scope
The purpose of this policy is to identify the statutory responsibilities of the Trust
when admitting and treating any patient identified with a mental health (MH) condition/disorder and to offer guidance on how responsibilities are to be carried out.
Patient safety is a key focus and where the patient's conditions are linked to

mental health, this policy offers practical support and guidance on collaborative working as well as diagnostic tools to ensure they are treated appropriately to protect themselves and/or others from harm.
All patients have a right to emergency and elective treatment for their condition

and the mental health concerns of the patient must always be taken into consideration. This policy aims to help staff improve the care of patients with mental ill health who access emergency care services.
A further intention set out in this policy for anyone involved in providing care for
patients with a mental health need, to provide faster, better treatment for mental health patients in a crisis and overall improve their experience of services.
This policy applies to:
Those patients brought into the Emergency Department (ED) by the police under Section 135 and 136 and who are requiring medical treatment
Those patients self-presenting to ED and who have a mental health condition including self-harm and suicidal thoughts
Those patients known to have mental health conditions and brought in by ambulance as an emergency
Those patients with an underlying mental health condition and being admitted to an elective service with inpatient status
Those patients with mental health concerns who are required to be admitted for a period of time due to their acute medical condition

Sections 132 (detained inpatients) and 132A (Community Treatment Order patients) require the Trust to take steps as are practicable to ensure a detained patient understands: a) under which provision of the Mental Health Act the patient is detained and the effect of that provision; and b) what rights of applying to the Mental Health Tribunal Services and the Hospital Managers are available to them in respect of their detention under that provision Sections 132 and 132A state that the above steps shall be taken as soon as practicable after the commencement of the patient's detention under the provision in question. The information has to be given to the patient both orally and in writing, this should not be referred to by staff as reading the patient their rights which has criminal justice overtones, it is important to see this as a process of providing information to the patient so that they have a better understanding of their situation in hospital. (Please see appendix 13)

Section 135 of the Mental Health Act allows the police to enter a person's home and take them to a place of safety, after first having obtained a warrant. This will usually be a specialist Place of Safety suite at a mental health hospital. However, Section 135 patients might attend the Emergency Department to have their physical health needs met or injuries attended to.
If a person appears to a constable to be suffering from mental disorder and to be in immediate need of care or control, the constable may, if he thinks it necessary to do so

Adult and Child Safeguarding Operational Groups oversee all operational
safeguarding activity (including the application of the Mental Capacity Act) including training compliance and adherence to policies.
MSE Group Adult and Child Safeguarding Committee oversees assurance to

the Trust Board that policies, systems and procedures and in place, disseminated and adhered to, to safeguard children, young people and adults at risk. Provides assurance on the implementation, monitoring and updating of policies, systems, and procedures within the Trust for safeguarding children, young people, and adults at risk. Responding to changes in local and national guidance, legislation, and best practice.
The Trust Board / Executive Committee has overall responsibility for ensuring

the Trust makes an effective contribution towards inter-agency working with partner agencies and for appropriately prioritising all aspects of safeguarding (including Mental Capacity Act 2005) safeguarding adults at risk and its allocation of resources for service and professional training and development. This includes representation at Safeguarding Adult Board Meetings / Partnerships and Subgroups. The Board has nominated the Chief Nurse and Director of Nursing to be responsible for assuring the safety and welfare of adults at risk, and for updating the relevant policies and ensuring that the necessary procedures are available for all staff.
MSE Chief Nurse

The Chief Nurse is the Director with responsibility for mental Health within MSE. They will act for and on behalf of the Trust to ensure processes are in place to manage the risks associated with mental health including implementing and monitoring this policy.
Site Directors of Nursing, Heads of Nursing, Matrons, Ward Sisters/ Charge
Nurses, Allied Health Professionals, Team Leaders and all Health Professionals:

Are responsible to ensure that steps are taken to implement the requirements of Trust policies and management guidelines including completion of incident report forms and root cause analysis where indicated.

Have a duty to ensure that patients are given information about the conditions of their detention and that copies are provided to the nearest relative. A record should be kept of how, when, where and by whom this information was given.
All Employees

All Employees have an individual responsibility and accountability in the provision of safe and competent practice and are expected to adhere to Trust policies and follow the guidelines to prevent risks to themselves and others.
All healthcare providers must ensure that there are systems in place to protect the safety and wellbeing of patients in their care.
Police (Constable)

It is the responsibility of the Police to make the decision on the use of S136 Mental Health Act 1983 as amended – Mentally Disordered Persons found in Public Place, rather than use other powers or resources to deal with a situation. If a decision is made not to use S136, as the person agrees to attend Emergency Department, then the police must be aware that the Crisis Team do not have powers to detain him/her unless s/he is detained under the MHA.

It is the responsibility of the Police to make arrangements for conveying the person subject to s136 to the place of safety and for accompanying the person there. Prior to conveying a person, if they are identified as requiring medical attention and are subject to a s136, the Police should inform the Police Control Room who in turn will inform the relevant Emergency Department that they are on their way.
Approved Mental Health Professional

All persons detained under S136 should be interviewed by an AMHP with a view to making any necessary arrangements for the person's treatment or care except where the doctor is of the opinion that the person does not currently suffer from a mental disorder and can be discharged mental disorder and can be discharged.

The AMHP must interview the person “in a suitable manner”, balancing the urgency of the situation against factors affecting communication such as the short- term effects of sedation or intoxication, or the need to arrange for an interpreter.

When assessing the person for detention under The Mental Health Act, the AMHP has overall responsibility for co-ordinating the process of assessment and any actions which need to be taken as a result.
It is the AMHP's duty, when two medical recommendations have been made, to decide whether or not to make an application to a named hospital for the detention of the person who has been assessed.

If the AMPH makes an application for detention, s/he has the power to take the person to hospital. This power may be delegated to others (MHA s6 [1]). The form of transport should be the most humane and least threatening, consistent with ensuring that no harm comes to the patient or others.
Any member of staff involved in an event involving a mental health patient can obtain immediate advice and support from their line manager or the mental Health Liaison Team
Independent Mental Health Advocate
An IMHA is an independent specialist advocate who provides additional safeguards for patients under the MHA.
They support patients to obtain relevant information and to exercise their rights to ensure patient participation in the decisions affecting their care and treatment.
They work collaboratively with other services including generic advocacy and other services.
The same advocate may be qualified to act as an IMHA or IMCA although the roles are completely different.
Management of Patients presenting with mental health needs / disorders from Emergency Department through to discharge or admission.
Section 135 & Section 136 of the Mental Health Act
S 135 of the Mental Health Act allows the police to obtain a warrant in order to

enter a person's home and take them to a PoS. The PoS will usually be a specialist suite at a mental health hospital. The permitted period of detention under Section 136 is 24 hours, during which time an assessment by a medical practitioner and AMHP to determine any necessary care arrangements should be undertaken. However, S 135 patients might attend ED to have their physical health needs met or injuries attended to.
S 136 of the Mental Health Act allows the police to take a patient from a public

space to a PoS, commonly a specialist suite at a mental health facility or the ED to have their physical health needs met or injuries attended to. The permitted period of detention under S 136 is 24 hours, during which time an assessment by a medical practitioner and AMHP to determine any necessary care arrangements should be undertaken. The section is a police power and means the police officer does not need a warrant or the input of a mental health professional to bring the patient to a PoS.
The primary difference between these two sections is the police and a mental
health professional will have secured a warrant to enter a person's home on a Section 135.
After the person is detained by the police the aim of both sections is to help the
person, by taking them to a PoS, i.e. a mental health hospital or sometimes a general hospital.
The majority of patients that are brought to the ED by the police under a temporary

section will be under a S 136. Staff need to be aware of the S 135. After the patient arrives in our Emergency Department under a S 135 the patient should be managed as per a Section 136 patient. (Refer to Police Section 136 Detention Process; Appendix 7).
Guided by a legal framework and their code of conduct, S 136 empowers the

Police, to make a judgement on whether to detain an individual under a S136 if they believe that person has a mental illness, is in a public place and in need of care. The S136 provides emergency powers for the Police to deprive a person of their liberty temporarily.
If a person appears to a constable to be suffering from mental disorder and to be
in immediate need of care or control and the person is in a public place, the constable may, if he thinks it necessary to do so in the interests of that person or for the protection of other persons:
a) remove the person to a place of safety within the meaning of Section 136, or
b) if the person is already at a place of safety within the meaning of that section, keep the person at that place or remove the person to another place of safety.
Police can take people under S 136 from a public place to a health based place of

safety or Section136 suite if the individual is in extreme mental distress and need to be detained for their own safety and the safety of others. A health based PoS is a place where mental health professionals can assess an individual's needs and work out next steps. A health based PoS is not an admission ward. An individual may be detained using the MHA for the purposes of assessing whether they have a mental disorder and if so whether they require further assessment or treatment.
A PoS can be a hospital if there is a medical need, or a police station in cases of

exceptional circumstances of risk, serious injury or death to anyone. No-one under 18 detained under S136 can be brought into a police station under any circumstances as per the Police and Crime act  Children of any age may be detained using S 136 MHA 1983, and any person under 18 years of age may be taken into police protection using Section 46 of the Children Act 1989
The Mental Health Act 1983 (Places of Safety) Regulations 2017 (legislation.gov.uk)
New rules restricting the use of police cells as places of safety come into effect - GOV.UK (www.gov.uk)
The Police can move the person between places of safety within the  hour

period of detention. The transfer of a detained person legally requires authorisation by an AMHP or a Police Officer. Coordinating the conveyance of individuals between health based places of safety and ED departments and vice versa should be undertaken by the Mental Health Trusts and Acute Trusts respectively. Coordinating and arranging transport is not the police's role unless there is mutual agreement between parties that it is in the best interest of the individual and there is resource to provide support
The Police can detain a person on a S 136 for up to  hours. This cannot be
renewed.
The Police have the power to search a detained person for items that may cause
harm to themselves and others and to retain any object.
If the Police make a decision not to use S136 because the individual agrees to
attend the Emergency Department, then the police must be aware that the Emergency Department staff do not have powers to detain the person unless the person is detained under the MHA.
A member of ED staff will contact the Mental Health Liaison Team (EPUT) located

within the ED departments. On arrival the receptionist will check the patient in and record their S136 status on the electronic patient record system. The Police must clearly specify the patient is under a Section 136 and requiring medical treatment giving an identified reason.
Following any necessary medical treatment and an assessment from the Mental

Health Liaison Team (EPUT) a referral is made to the AMHP and the Section 12 doctors. They will carry out the mental health assessment, once the patient is deemed to be medically fit and will carry out their interview in a designated place of safety.
The Police should be handing over as soon as is practicable unless high / medium

risk (refer to the S 136 ED handover process chart for full explanation of the process; Appendix 8). As agreed with Essex Police, the police officers will only hand over the patient to a doctor or the nurse in charge of the department. Security officers and other staff who are not senior members of the Emergency Department will not sign the A287 Form.
At the end of the mental health assessment, the powers to detain the person
lapse. There should only be one of three outcomes:
Discharge from ED or within the hospital if deemed medically fit with follow up consideration to EPUT
Informal admission to a psychiatric ward or medical centre - EPUT.
Admission to a mental health unit detained under Section 2 or 3 MHA
Any decision for admission to psychiatric facilities on a formal or informal basis will
be undertaken by EPUT.
Assessment & Triage
The Triage Nurse in the ED will provide verbal and written information about the care process in a language and format the patient understands in line with Accessible Information Standard.
Provide a safe and supportive environment where people can wait, and provide
supervision to ensure safety, if appropriate, with a named member of staff. In addition, the use of a dedicated mental health quiet room where appropriate.
ED staff responsible for triage will use a preliminary combined physical and mental
health triage scale by:
Urgently establishing the physical risk and mental state in respectful and understanding way.
Taking account of the patient's emotional distress as well as physical distress.
Remembering that some people who self-harm may not show distress even when the injury is severe.
The Triage nurse will carry out an assessment to determine the patient's:
Mental capacity
Willingness to remain for further psychosocial assessment
Distress levels
Presence of mental illness
The triage nurse will start The Joint Adult Mental Health Assessment and Referral

Form (Appendix 1) and the Preliminary Mental Health Risk Assessment (Section 2). This form will be emailed to the Mental Health Liaison Team (EPUT) when the patient is deemed medically fit for discharge and ready for a mental health assessment. The triage nurse might ask the Mental Health Liaison Team to come and perform a joint triage depending on the patients physical health needs.
The Triage Nurse will document all actions and interventions following

assessment. This will include written details of referral to other team(s), telephone calls/any advice given and discharge/transfer or follow-up plans. See Appendix 8 (Further guidance for patients presenting with self-harm / suicidal ideations to ED) and Appendix 9 (Duty of care on the assessment of intoxicated patients).
Where people are waiting for physical treatments, the psychosocial assessment
can be delayed when (see section 5.23 further guidance on psychosocial assessments) :
The patient needs life-saving treatment
The patient is unconscious
The patient is incapable of assessment (e.g. intoxicated)
The patient will be treated in accordance with Trust protocols in the same way as

any other patient awaiting treatment. Consideration should always be given to additional aspects of presentation such as physical illness or intoxication – as this would impact on time scales, assessment and review. In the event that treatment required is identified as minor, the Police Officers should be escorted with the patient to a safe space within the department as the department pressures allow. If the treatment required is of a more serious nature then a bay in Majors in view of the main nurse base must be used. Police will not remain with the detained person whilst an assessment is being made (refer to the Section 136 ED handover process chart for full explanation of the process; Appendix 7).
When offering appropriate treatment according to patient presentation, the level of
sedation required for patient safety must be balanced against the need to make a full assessment under the MHA (See MSE Restrictive Interventions Policy).
The patient may refuse treatment. If so, treatment can only be given on an
emergency basis within the provisions of the MCA.
Where any restrictive interventions are carried out including sedation then these
must be documented and reported via the Trust incident reporting system. (See MSE Restrictive interventions policy).
Once the patient has received treatment and is deemed to be medically fit for

discharge the patient must not remain in ED but will be transferred/escorted transferred to a mental health suite as soon as their physical health permits, so they can receive the mental health care and treatment for which they have been detained.
Holding powers under S5 (2) & S5 (4) MHA cannot be used in ED or OPD. These
two sections only apply to inpatients.
If a patient is already in hospital and the doctor in charge of care or treatment, or
their nominated deputy, can make a decision about whether to detain the patient under a Section 5(2) for mental health assessment.
Section 5(2) gives doctors the ability to detain someone in hospital for up to 72
hours, during which time you should receive an assessment that decides if further detention under the MHA is necessary.

Staff should be trained to receive section papers and be knowledgeable in the legal requirement.

The care of the patient should be a partnership approach between MSE and

Patients must be kept informed of their rights under S 132 MHA.  In-patient – Mental Health Liaison Team (MHLT)

There will be occasions when patients who are already detained under S2 or S3
(or other formal section of the Act) at another care facility for treatment for a
mental disorder will need a concurrent treatment within MSE for a physical
disorder. In situations where a patient requires transfer to the premises of the
Trust, such transfer should preferably be made under S19. This provides EPUT
with the full holding powers to prevent the patient leaving MEHT hospital premises. (Refer to Appendix 3).Patients detained under S2 or S3 MHA would normally be

transferred on S 19 to the acute Trust for treatment. Transfers under S17 Leave will be discouraged as these are most often used for day or weekend leave from a psychiatric facility (See Appendix 3). S17 leave can be useful for brief admissions to acute hospital from a MH hospital – it is a matter for the mental health provider in discussion with the receiving hospital
Detained patients are to be reminded that they can have support from the
Independent Mental Health Advocacy services.
The patient's RC must refer them to a RC at the receiving hospital/unit.
The receiving hospital/unit must agree to the acceptance and subsequent transfer
of the patient.
The Consultant Psychiatrist will retain overall responsibility for their mental health
care and treatment.
Additional mental health staff would be supplied on a 1:1 basis where clinical need
and risk indicates.
Consent to Treatment for mental disorder under the Mental Health Act
In the MHA Code of Practice, “medical treatment” includes nursing, psychological
intervention and specialist mental health facilitation, rehabilitation and care.
The MHA defines medical treatment for mental disorder as medical treatment
which is for the purpose of alleviating or preventing a deterioration of a mental disorder or one or more of its symptoms or manifestations.
This includes treatment of physical health problems only to the extent that such

treatment is part of, or ancillary to, treatment for mental disorder, e.g. treating wounds self-inflicted as a result of mental disorder. Otherwise, the MHA does not regulate medical treatment for physical health problems. Close consultation with the patient's RC will be necessary. Where it is not clear, or there is disagreement as to whether the treatment is required as a physical consequence of the mental disorder, consider seeking advice from the Legal Team.
Although the MHA permits some medical treatment for mental disorder to be given
without consent, the patient's consent should still be sought before treatment is given, wherever practicable. If staff are in any doubt, please seek advice.
The patient's consent or refusal should be recorded in their records.
Staff should familiarise themselves with the MCA and organisational policy

surrounding consent to treatment. Where it is felt that the patient lacks capacity, the basic principles of the MCA should be applied. MCA documentation should be completed and kept in patient medical notes.
If the patient has capacity and the treatment offered is not for the mental health
condition/disorder then the patient can refuse treatment. (Refer to Appendix 4)
For further guidance on patients presenting with self-harm/suicidal ideations to
hospital see Appendix
For further guidance on duty of care on the assessment of intoxicated patients See
Appendix
For further guidance on patients with learning disabilities/autism and mental health
issues see Appendix
Managing children & young people who self harm
In the eyes of the law, a person is a child until they reach 18 – at which point they are an adult
Child – under 16 years of age Young person – 16/17 years of age Adult – 18 years of age and above
Professionals, practitioners and all others responsible for the care of children and
young people should be familiar with legislation set out within the MHA; Children's Act, 1989and Human Rights Act 1998. The MHA applies to people of all ages.
Children under 16 years of age who have self-harmed should be triaged, assessed
and treated by appropriately trained children's nurses and doctors in a separate children's area of the emergency department.
The Children's Safeguarding Team should be alerted and informed of admission if
it is believed there is a safeguarding or abuse concern.
Children's triage nurses should be trained in the assessment and early
management of mental health problems and, in particular, in the assessment and early management of children and young people who have self-harmed.
Children and young people will be assessed by EWMHs who will decide if the
young person requires admission or can be discharged when medically fit.
Alternative placements may be required, depending upon the age of the child,

circumstances of the child and their family, the time of presentation to services, child protection issues and the physical and mental health of the child; this might include a transfer to a child or adolescent psychiatric inpatient unit where necessary.
For young people (see age definitions above) ho have self-harmed, admission to
an adult ward may be considered if this is available and preferred by the young person.
A paediatrician should normally have overall responsibility for the treatment and

care of children and young people who have been admitted following an act of self-harm by a young person up to the age of  Adult wards should be encouraged to seek advice from paediatric services and / or the safeguarding team if there is a concern whoever has medical responsibility for the young person.
Following admission of a child or young person who has self-harmed, the
admitting team should obtain parental (or other legally responsible adult) consent for mental health assessment of the child or young person.
Staff who have emergency contact with children and young people who have self-
harmed should have access at all times to specialist advice about issues surrounding mental capacity and consent and how it applies to this patient group.
The MCA does not apply to medical treatment for children under 16. In the

assessment and treatment of self-harm in children special attention should be paid to the issues of confidentiality, the young person's consent (including whether they are “Gillick competent”) (See MSEPO-190010 Child Safeguarding Policy), parental responsibility & parental consent, child protection, the use of the MHA in young people and the Children's Act.
During admission to a paediatric ward following self-harm, the Emotional

Wellbeing & Mental Health Service (EWMHS) should undertake assessment and provide consultation for the young person, his or her family, the paediatric team and social services and education staff as appropriate.
During hospital admission, the EWMHS team should:
Provide consultation for the child and young person, their family, the paediatric team, social services, and education staff
Undertake assessment addressing needs and risk for the child, the family, the social situation of the family and young person, and child protection issues
Assessors should be specifically trained and supervised to work with self-harm in this age group
Hospital staff should advise parents/carers to remove all means of self-harm,
including medication, before the child or young person returns home.
Psychosocial Assessments
Prescribed nurses are generally those clinical staff assigned to undertake a full
psychosocial & risk assessment. These include Psychiatric Clinicians – Mental Health Liaison and EWMHS.
Upon referral patients will be seen for assessment as soon as possible in ED.
Where possible this assessment will be undertaken in the privacy of the mental health assessment room next to the bed office.
For inpatients admitted to a ward, urgent cases will be seen as soon as possible
depending on priority.
The aim of the psychosocial assessments is:
To assess the degree to which the patient or others is at risk
To assess whether the patient is suffering from a mental illness
To obtain a detailed picture of why the patient committed an act of self-harm at this particular time
Whenever possible, with the patient's consent, the patient's partner/significant
other/Carer will be involved in the assessment process, informing them of relevant decisions.
The assessor will communicate the outcome of the assessment including planned
interventions and advise hospital staff; the GP and/or Community Services (if involved) by face to face; written documentation; telephone / fax – timescales indicated by clinical need.
If the patient requires a referral to specialist mental health services, social or
voluntary services, the assessor will make this referral – timescale as indicated by clinical need.
For further guidance on self-harm / suicidal patients who abscond from the
hospital see Appendix
For guidance on missing persons refer to MSE Missing & Absconding Patients
Policy.
Transfer of Self Harm patients to other health care facilities
It is generally the responsibility of the ward or department transferring out to make
the necessary transport arrangements unless a secure ambulance is required. Seek advice if needed.
Points to consider, in consultation with the Access & Assessment Team:
Likelihood of harm to others, e.g. nurse escort, ambulance personnel
Whether the patient is co-operative
Whether the patient is fully mobile
Whether the patient is sedated
Likelihood of immediate further harm to self
Patients at risk of further self-harm will be transported in an ambulance. A

paramedic / technician will accompany the patient in the back of the ambulance. When booking an ambulance severity of risk must be communicated to the person generating the booking as it has been known that some mental health patients jump from the back of moving vehicles.
If patients are commenced on 1:1 increased observation this must continue during
transfer until the patient reaches their destination.
Where there is significant risk towards patient and others then a secure
ambulance will be required (UKSAS), authorised by AMHP. The rationale for organising the chosen transport arrangements must be clearly documented in the patient's nursing notes.
If the patient has been detained under a section of the MHA, and is to be

transferred to another hospital site from a medical / surgical ward, it is the responsibility of the ward staff, in close consultation with the AMHP and the Crisis Team, to make the necessary transport arrangements. Patients held under Section 5(2) of the Mental Health Act cannot be transferred. For transfer to take place the patient needs to be further assessed for a section 2 or 3 MHA, which needs to be carried out by medical staff approved under section 12 of the MHA, or the section 5(2) can be rescinded by the consultant in charge of the patient, if the patient is willing to accept treatment on a voluntary informal basis.
Incidents on hospital premises associated with self-harm/ attempted suicide
Any incidents of self-harm on the hospital site should be dealt with by ward staff
immediately, reported to the Ward Manager and escalated up to Lead Nurses.
Incidents out of hours should be reported to the Clinical Operations Manager and
to the Senior Manager on Call.
If the patient was known to be at risk of self-harming and was not monitored
adequately when it was identified that additional care was needed then this should be incident reported and raised as a potential serious incident in line with organisational policy.
If a patient identified as at risk harms a staff member or another patient or member

of the public, this should be reported to security, the Police and the Ward Manager immediately, escalation to the Clinical Operations manager and On Call Manager for action is also required. Immediate risk assessments and preventative measures will need to be undertaken to prevent further incidents occurring.
Any event of an attempted suicide on site will be treated as a potential serious
incident immediately and should be escalated in line with the Trust policy.
Immediate measures in collaboration with EPUT should be taken by the ward and
Clinical Operations Managers to ensure the safety of the patient.
A incident report should be completed in the event of any incident involving a
patient at risk of self-harming or attempting suicide.
Debrief all staff involved/witness to the incident and offer support as appropriate.  Incidents of suicide on hospital premises
The event of an actual suicide on site will require immediate escalation as a
Serious Incident in line with the Trust Serious Incident Policy.
Essex Police should be notified upon discovery of the event by dialling 999 to
report the event.
Security should be called to lock down the area immediately until Essex Police
arrive on scene. If there are members of the public, family or relatives in the area they must be asked to leave the area.
The incident should be escalated to the Director of Nursing and Medical Director
during working hours and the Clinical Operations Manager out of hours.
The clinical Operations Manager; will escalate to the Senior Manager on Call; the
Executive director on Call & the Health and Safety Manager as soon as possible. The Health and Safety Manager will act as Police Liaison for the event.
The scene of a suicide must not be disturbed and all evidence must be preserved
and retained.
If the incident takes place in an open bay or department then it is important for
privacy and dignity and to maintain calm amongst other patients by drawing curtains around the scene, placing portable screens up if appropriate; and covering window panes on doors.
A debrief session must be offered to all staff involved/witness to the incident and
support offered as appropriate.
People who wish to leave before assessment and/or treatment
If a person wishes to leave the hospital before a psychosocial assessment has
been completed, assess for mental capacity/mental illness and record assessment in the notes.
If the person has capacity then pass assessment details to the service user's GP
and to the relevant mental health services as soon as possible, to enable rapid follow up.
If mental capacity is diminished and/or the person has a significant mental illness,
refer for urgent mental health assessment and call security for back up to prevent the person from leaving.
Ethical Control & Restraint
Please refer to Restrictive Interventions Policy.
Risk Assessment & Risk Event Reporting for Patients under S136
Inpatients admitted under S 136 must have a formal risk assessment completed to
ensure that staff and patients safety are considered during the period of stay as an inpatient.
Incidents involving any S136 Patient, Police officer or staff member should be
reported on to the Ward Manager, Associate Nurse, Clinical Operations Manager and to the LSMS.
A Risk Event Report (Concise) should also be completed as soon as possible
following the event and sent to the Risk Management Team.
It is not usually possible to eliminate all risks but hospital staff has a duty to protect
patients as far as ‘reasonably practicable' and should avoid taking any unnecessary risks.
Training requirements
Mental health awareness training should be available to staff.
Ethical Control and Restraint including site training is provided to the Security/
Porters of MEHT and is defined in the Trust TNA.
Monitoring and audit
It is the responsibility of the Chief Nurse to monitor compliance of this policy.  Trends and any actions will be monitored by the MSE Safeguarding Committee.
Monthly analysis of the reported restraint incidences will be carried out by the
Safeguarding Group (See Restrictive Interventions Policy).

Appendix 5: Providing 1:1 observation of the patient guidance
PROVIDING 1:1 OBSERVATION OF THE PATIENT

The nurse in charge must assess for the appropriate grade, role and skills required if a patient requires enhanced observation. Refer to Enhanced Observation Policy and Restrictive Interventions Policy.
The staff member should position themselves at a safe distance between the patient and the door, but not blocking the exit.
The staff member's total concentration must be on the patient at all times.
The staff member is not responsible for the care or observation of any other patient.
The patient must not be left alone at any time. The staff member remains with the patient even during reviews by the medical team and/or other health professionals.
Issues of privacy and dignity are important but safety and security take precedence.

Ensure that the patient's immediate environment is safe and check the patient's belongings for hazards e.g. lighters, matches, dressing gown or pyjama cords, glass bottles, nail files, scissors, razors or blades. Remove all unnecessary equipment such as 02 tubing, nurse call cord, chairs. Eliminate any ready access to means of self-harm or harm to others. Beware of the ingenuity of people who want to self-harm or suicide. Items such as bin liners, plastic bags and tourniquets can be dangerous. Check the bed and bed linens once each shift to ensure the patient is not hoarding anything that could be used to harm self or others.
Ensure that the patient actually swallows any medication administered to them.
If the staff member needs to leave the bedside, ensure relief is organised before leaving the patient's bedside for any period of time whatsoever.
Keep a discreet distance but never leave a patient who is under 1:1 observation alone in the care of a relative

The patient may not always want to talk about their reason for admission, current stressors or past life events. It should not be assumed that is always appropriate to engage the patient in discussion of their problems. Sometimes it may be appropriate to provide distraction for the patient by allowing them to read, play cards, listen to music or watch television or engaging them in general conversation not related to their illness. It is not appropriate for the staff member to offer advice to the patient.
If the patient does want to discuss their current situation, the staff member should listen and be empathic.
Reassure the patient that they will be safe and protected. Feeling suicidal can be very frightening for people.
Ask for an urgent clinical review if there is a sudden change in the patient's mental state or if they appear to become more agitated or distressed.
Staff members providing 1:1 observations should not use their phone, read, study or attend to any other activity that potentially distracts them from observing and caring for the patient.
The staff member must not wear lanyards, a stethoscope or anything else around their neck (e.g. jewellery) if the patient is at risk of harm to others.

Appendix 8: Further guidance for patients presenting with Self Harm/Suicidal ideations to hospital, ED to admission
On arrival a verbal hand over and a copy of an Ambulance sheet if applicable is to be given to ED staff.
Record the person's details on the electronic patient record system and generate Emergency Department notes.

5.35 Details of patients who are frequent re-attenders will have their details recorded on the ED computer system. The electronic patient record system should be checked for any additional information including other services/Agencies involved.

The Triage Nurse will assess the person. If a patient is showing signs of distress or not wanting to wait for assessment or treatment this should be escalated as a priority to ensure they receive the appropriate assessment/treatment in a timely manner.

Patients who have self-harmed should have a risk assessment completed in the ED. Staff should always use proper anaesthesia and/or analgesia if planned treatment for self-injury is known to be painful

A base line assessment, to determine the subsequent risk of further self-harm will be undertaken by the doctor/nurse examining the patient, using the Mental Health Risk Assessment Matrix. (Refer to Appendix 2)
This assessment should determine a person's mental capacity, their willingness to remain for further (psychosocial) assessment, their level of distress and the possible presence of mental illness.
Where possible, this assessment will be undertaken in the privacy of private area and environment that is equally safe, supportive and minimises any distress.
For many patients, this may be a separate, quiet room with supervision and regular contact with a named member of staff to ensure safety.
The assessment - together with the date and time - must be clearly documented in the clinical notes.

The Risk Assessment Matrix is an aid to clinical decision making. These do not remove the need for further professional judgement, involvement, or the importance of accessing the mental Health Liaison Team (EPUT) when planning interventions or making discharge decisions.
Following completion of assessment one of the following management options will apply:
- Referral on to the appropriate medical/surgical team for further assessment and treatment of the patient's physical condition
- Admission to the A&E Observation ward/Emergency Assessment unit or Emergency Short Stay
- Referral to the Mental Health Liaison Team or the Senior Nurse Practitioner with the Mental Health Liaison Team's at EPUT
- Discharge with follow up arrangements
The rationale for whichever option is chosen must also be clearly documented in the clinical notes.
All self-harm patients will be offered a full psycho-social assessment - medical condition permitting, as soon as possible.

A copy of the ED notes of all self-harm patients who leave directly from ED without a full psychosocial assessment must be left for the Mental Health Liaison Team (EPUT) to follow up, in the ED Reception area.

If the patient is of no fixed abode, the patient must be offered the contact telephone numbers and address of EPUT and the addresses of local centres to obtain the support required for their condition.

If a person wishes to leave before a psychosocial assessment is carried out, assess for mental capacity/mental illness and record assessment in the notes. If patient has capacity then pass a copy of the assessment to the service user's GP and to the relevant mental health services as soon as possible, to enable rapid follow up.
If mental capacity is diminished and/or the person has a significant mental illness, refer for urgent mental health assessment and prevent the person leaving by calling Security for assistance.

All patients that are going to be left alone in a bed space/side room should have the room/bed space considered for ligature risks. The Joint Adult Mental Health Assessment and Referral Form contains a Ligature checklist for staff to complete if warranted. Always ask the patient if you can search their belongings for weapons/objects that might be used to self-harm and any medications or potential ligatures. Please always document any searches of a room or conversations with patient about searches in the patient's notes. Staff can ask to search a patients belongings and their property but have no legal right to search if the patient declines. Staff should never search a patients property alone.
Acute Admission of Patients who Self Harm

Priority must be given to placing the patient in a safe environment. If an acceptable ward area is not available immediately the patient should remain in a place of safety (ED, AMU or Mental Health Suite) where they are deemed to be safe until appropriate placement becomes available. The Mental Health Team should be involved in this decision particularly if they are going to be actively involved in the subsequent assessment, treatment and care of the patient.

When admitting a patient to the hospital with self-harm injuries or a history of self- harming then a Trust risk assessment proforma must be undertaken prior to their transfer from ED to identify the safest location for the patient based on their clinical need.
Before the patient leaves the ED department, staff must check that all appropriate investigations have been undertaken and the results reviewed.

Initially based on their medical state and risk assessment, Patients are to be admitted to an Observation Ward, Emergency Assessment Unit, Emergency Short Stay Unit for organisational reasons, in the event that a further transfer to a specialised ward is required i.e. trauma, orthopaedic, surgical etc then a risk assessment or review must be undertaken prior to the transfer to the allocated ward.

Matron should be notified, clear written documentation and face to face handover should be undertaken by the qualified A&E staff involved in the patient's care to the qualified ward staff taking over their care using SBAR.
When the patient arrives on the ward, the staff needs to check the investigations ordered via ED and follow up on the results of the investigations made as appropriate.

Consideration must be given to the location, objects in the room and accessibility of objects able to cause harm. All appropriate steps must be taken to mitigate the chance of harm whenever a patient is admitted who may be contemplating self- harm or harm to others.

Staff should remove any items from the bed space and surrounding area that could be harmful to the patient e.g. ligature points, loose sharp objects, crockery. The Joint Adult Mental Health Assessment and Referral Form contain a Ligature checklist for staff to complete if required.
Relatives and carers should only be involved in the management of the patient if the patient has given appropriate consent unless unable to do so.
Priority should be given to providing a special for the care of this patient on a 1:1 basis until the full extent of their condition is known.
Patients who verbally threaten self-harm or who actively try to self-harm in the ward area must be observed 1:1 at all times and security called to offer support.

A referral to the Tissue Viability Service for advice on treatment of acute wounds caused by self-harm may be necessary, as some patients may have unusual wounds that fail to respond to treatment – clinicians need to be aware that the patient may not openly divulge that they have a wound that is not healing.
Ward staff should accurately document the patient's behaviour and subsequent management; Complete incident forms where appropriate and maintain contact and communication with the mental health staff.
Appendix 9: Duty of Care on the Assessment of Intoxicated Patients
Intoxication can occur with clinical significant signs and symptoms associated with recent ingestion of a substance not attributable to any other medical or psychological condition.

It is important to treat alcohol abuse as a primary disease process whilst recognising the co-existence of other mental disorders. The rationale for treating the substance use first is that the drug use typically interferes with an accurate assessment of their underlying psychiatric disorder. What looks like a serious personality disorder or depression can clearly improve when the alcohol wears off.

The ED doctor, having assessed the intoxicated patient, who is also thought to have a mental health problem, will decide whether the patient is fit for psychiatric assessment. Contact the Alcohol Liaison Nurse Specialist.

In the event that the patient is too intoxicated and not fit for further assessment then the ED doctor with the involvement of the Mental Health Liaison Team (EPUT) /Alcohol Liaison Nurse Specialist should document in the patient's notes that they will review the patient within a specific time.

However, if the ED doctor is seriously concerned about the safety of the individual and the primary concern is that of the patient's mental health then the ED doctor should consider a mental health assessment.

Following receipt of referral, the Mental Health Liaison Team (EPUT) will attend the ED Department and will attempt to make an initial mental health assessment. If the Mental Health Liaison Team finds the patient to be intoxicated to such an extent that the assessment is impossible, this should be fully explained to the referring ED doctor and the patient's Named Nurse.

The initial assessment is to be documented in the patient's notes and plan of care agreed, including a timescale of when the Mental Health Liaison Team (EPUT) will re-assess the patient, advice on management issues that may arise, and a plan of action i.e.: if the patient wants to leave the ED Department, the patient should sign a self discharge form and have the risk explained.

If the person wanting to leave is deemed at serious risk or lacks capacity, efforts should be made under a duty of care to discourage them from leaving, involve Security and ask the Police for assistance as appropriate. Contact Mental Health Liaison /Home Treatment and Crisis Resolution team and express the urgency with which their presence is required.

In such instances the duty of care will be collaborated between the Mental Health Liaison Team (EPUT) and the ED Department. From this point onwards a degree of flexibility is required by both services; the patient's best interest is of prime importance.
The Mental Health Liaison Team (EPUT) should reassess the patient at the earliest opportunity, as agreed, to prevent any further deterioration in mental health.
Appendix 10: Patients with Learning Disabilities/Autism and Mental Health Issues

There is often a blurring between mental illness and learning disabilities, especially in cases with a dual diagnosis. If a patient who has a dual diagnosis (or suspected) of a learning disability or autism coupled with mental health issues then the same procedures apply as above but with additional input/joint working from the relevant
Advice can be sought from the Learning Disability Services / Hospital Learning Disability Nurse who should be informed of any LD clients that present.
The LD Nurse will also give advice on any reasonable adjustments required for this patient group – i.e. risks; communication; capacity, consent; levels of support; transfers.
Where the HLN is unavailable then contact should be made to the Community LD Team (HPFT) as the patient may be known within the community.

Physical examination and assessments will be required to rule out any physical issues as it is widely known that physical symptoms can be overlooked and dismissed on the assumption that presenting behaviours are a part of the person's learning disability (diagnostic overshadowing).

People with LD/ASD & MH problems may not be well suited to generic MH inpatient services and therefore it is likely that where intensive community support has failed, an acute admission bed within specialised learning disability units will need to be authorised and commissioned.
Appendix 11: Self Harm/ Suicidal Patients who abscond from the hospital (Refer to Missing & Absconding Patients Policy)

Notify security immediately via switchboard, fast bleep for high risk missing patients. Inform security of a description and the risk of the patient being able to harm themselves or others if appropriate.

Based on the assessed level of risk associated with the patient leaving the hospital a decision will need to be made in line with the Missing Persons Policy, if the risk of the patient to themselves or others is deemed high, then Essex Police should be contacted as soon the patient has been identified as missing.
An incident form should be completed for any patient who has been reported as missing from the ward/Department. The report should also include the police incident number.
Appendix 12: Mental Health & Older Patients/ Dementia

Individuals presenting with signs and symptoms of dementia and/or confirmed diagnosis of dementia can fall within the MHA's definition of mental disorder. Patients with dementia in the hospital setting can pose particular challenges to delivering quality care.
People with dementia may present and behave in very different ways from those with other kinds of mental disorder. Effective communication is key to supporting people with the assessment process.
Professionals with appropriate skills, knowledge and expertise in supporting people with dementia should be involved in any decisions to use the MHA especially at times of crisis.

Consideration should be given in relation to old age and very old patients, for example the need to restrain appropriately taking account of physical status and frailty, and the misuse of medication as a particular risk.

Deterioration in ability, reflecting the aging process, needs to be carefully considered and attention paid to making reasonable adjustments to ensure that older people have the same access as younger people to information, and to protect their rights and promote their wellbeing.
A referral should be made to the site dementia nurse.
Refer to the MSE Dementia Policy.
Appendix 13: Section 132 information.
Section 132, 132A Information

1.1. As part of the admissions process, particular and relevant information should be given to each patient in order to ensure that the patient understands their legal rights about the nature and implications of admission on a Section.
1.2. The statutory information which must be given is:
The Section of the Act that authorises the patient's detention in hospital or compulsion in the community and the effects of that Section, including the maximum period the Section can last for.
A copy of his/her detention or community treatment order document/s including any subsequent renewals, extensions or change in statutory circumstances (e.g. the reasons for being recalled).

Patients' and Nearest Relatives' rights to appeal against further detention or Community Treatment Order to the Hospital Managers and/or the Mental Health Tribunal and the patient's right to be legally represented (a list of solicitors is available on inpatient units).
The patient's right to an Independent Mental Health Advocate (IMHA).

Information on consent to treatment including the nature, purpose and likely effects of any planned treatment, the patient's right to withdraw consent to treatment at any time, and how and when treatment can be given without their consent.
The Hospital Managers/Secretary of State's duty to refer certain cases to the MHT service.
The Trust complaints process.

The role of the Care Quality Commission and how a patient may complain to the Commission, (patients must be informed about a planned ward visit by a Commissioner and their right to talk to the Commissioner in private).
That correspondence for posting may be withheld if the recipient has asked the Hospital Managers to do so.
The duty of the Hospital Managers to inform the Nearest Relative of:

1.3. Sections 132 (detained inpatients) and 132A (Community Treatment Order patients) require the Trust to take steps as are practicable to ensure a detained patient understands: a) under which provision of the Mental Health Act the patient is detained and the effect of that provision; and b) what rights of applying to the Mental Health Tribunal Services and the Hospital Managers are available to them in respect of their detention under that provision Sections 132 and 132A state that the above steps shall be taken as soon as practicable after the commencement of the patient's detention under the provision in question.

The information has to be given to the patient both orally and in writing, this should not be referred to by staff as reading the patient their rights which has criminal justice overtones, it is important to see this as a process of providing information to the patient so that they have a better understanding of their situation in hospital

What are you proposing to change?
This is a review of an existing guideline that now reflects the new MSE Structure and unification of practice across all 3 sites.
Why are you making this change? (What will the change achieve?)

To ensure appropriate guidelines are in place to support staff at a service level and to ensure best interest decisions are undertaken within statutory requirements and the Mental Health Act. To ensure the guidance is applicable to all appropriate services within the MSE Group.
Who benefits from this change and how?

All individuals over the age of 16 where day to day or complex decisions are required. Staff – To support staff at a service level and to ensure best interest decisions are undertaken within statutory requirements.
